book_metadata.title: Game Feel: A Game Designer's Guide to Virtual Sensation
book_metadata.author: Steve Swink

signature_phrases.hint: Used to introduce a subtle or counterintuitive point after laying groundwork.
Used as a major transition to frame the next section's core problem.

Game Feel.definition: The tactile, kinesthetic sense of manipulating a virtual object; the sensation of control in a game, arising from real-time control, simulated space, and polish.
Game Feel.reinforcement_pattern: Used consistently and as the central subject throughout the book.

Virtual Proprioception.definition: An amplified impression of proprioception generated from visual, aural, and tactile feedback in a game, creating a sense of a virtual object's position, size, and weight.
Virtual Proprioception.reinforcement_pattern: Referred back to when discussing the player's sensory experience.

Proxied Embodiment.definition: The extension of a player's identity into a game avatar, making it feel like part of one's own body.
Proxied Embodiment.reinforcement_pattern: Used when discussing player identity and sensory extension.

core_thesis.statement: Game feel is the crucial, tactile sensation of control that makes games compelling; it is not magic, but a craftable result of the interplay between input, response, context, polish, metaphor, and rules, which can be understood, measured, and designed intentionally.

evolution.thesis_aspect: Game feel is a real, definable thing composed of three building blocks.
Game feel can be measured with a vocabulary of six metrics.
Mastering these metrics leads to universal principles for creating good game feel.

supporting_pillars.pillar: Game feel is an aesthetic of interaction, distinct from other media.
The player's perception, not objective reality, is the target for design.
Good feel can be deconstructed and reverse-engineered through analysis.

foundational.concept: Three Building Blocks of Game Feel
foundational.definition: The core components that create the experience: Real-Time Control, Simulated Space, and Polish.
A comprehensive diagram showing the feedback loop from player intent, through human processors, input devices, the computer, the game world, and back to the player's senses.

primary.concept: The Six Metrics (Input, Response, Context, Polish, Metaphor, Rules)

book_level.objective: To provide a vocabulary and framework for analyzing and creating game feel.
book_level.assessment: Reader can deconstruct a game using the six metrics and propose design changes.

primary.objective: Understand the definition of Game Feel and its core components.
Apply the six metrics to deconstruct the feel of Asteroids.

intentional_difficulty.reason: Introduces more academic HCI concepts and timings (ms).
intentional_difficulty.scaffolding_allowed: Connects directly to player reaction time, a familiar concept.

reader_progression_adjustment.if_struggling: Reinforce with the 'Try It Yourself' reaction time test.

redundancy_map.evolution: Introduced, then each is explored in its own chapter, then all are applied in case studies.

tension_arc.resolution: Chapter 17 synthesizes this knowledge into actionable principles.

internal_consistency.verify: Ensure the application of metrics in Part 3 is consistent with their definitions in Part 2.

reader_comprehension.target_range: Readers should be able to manipulate the examples and perceive the described changes in feel.

chapter_1.takeaway: Game feel is a real, definable thing, not just a vague quality.
chapter_1.verification_test: Reader can articulate the three building blocks.

chapter_7.takeaway: The motion of a game character over time can be graphed and understood as an ADSR envelope.
chapter_7.verification_test: Reader can explain the difference between a 'tight' and 'floaty' feel using ADSR terms.

common_conflicts.conflict: Condensing case studies vs. demonstrating the complexity of feel
common_conflicts.resolution: Prioritize preserving the relationships between parameters over describing every single effect.

common_conflicts.conflict: Technical jargon vs. accessibility for non-programmers
common_conflicts.resolution: Use analogies and visual diagrams heavily; keep code-level discussion to a minimum.

priority_hierarchy: 1. Preserve the core thesis and foundational definitions.
2. Maintain the integrity of the case study deconstructions.
3. Keep the author's conversational and educational voice.
4. Preserve the connection between text and 'Playable Examples'.
conflict_resolution.when_in_doubt: Err on the side of preserving detailed analysis over simplification.

metadata_gathering_workflow: 1. First pass: Read for voice and style patterns.
2. Second pass: Map out the conceptual hierarchy and pedagogical structure.
3. Third pass: Analyze one full case study (e.g., Super Mario Bros) to test the metric framework.
4. Fourth pass: Fill out the JSON based on the complete reading.
5. Iterate: Refine based on any inconsistencies found.

validation_method.ai_output_testing: Generate a summary of Chapter 13 and compare its preserved details against the 'never_reduce' rules.

metrics: Ability to apply the six metrics to a new game

implementation_notes.update_frequency: After processing each major section (Definitions, Metrics, Examples, Principles).
